message_1: If p is a prime number and a is any integer, what is the remainder when a to the power of (p-1) is divided by p?
message_2:
According to Fermat's Little Theorem, if p is a prime number and a is an integer not divisible by p, then a^(p-1) is congruent to 1 modulo p. In other words, the remainder when a^(p-1) is divided by p is 1.

Mathematically, this can be written as:

a^(p-1) â‰¡ 1 (mod p)

However, if a is divisible by p, then the remainder when a^(p-1) is divided by p is 0.

So, the remainder when a^(p-1) is divided by p is:

1, if a is not divisible by p (i.e., gcd(a, p) = 1)
0, if a is divisible by p (i.e., gcd(a, p) = p)
